node.text:
Watch the second episode of our Instagram live series ‘Let’s talk about’ with our clean energy and environment correspondent Leslie Hook and climate reporter Camilla Hodgson as they discuss the impact of climate change in different sectors and groups of people as well what can be done to mitigate it. 
For more climate content, follow @ftclimate
#climatechange #climate #nature #environment #economy #agriculture #electricvehicles #politics

node.text:
Is cryptocurrency here to stay? What’s the future of bitcoin? Will crypto ever surpass the dollar as the world’s main currency? And the infamous question, why is the FT’s coverage of crypto usually so negative?

Watch our live with FT Alphaville reporter @jemimajo and our tech reporter @mshannahmurphy as they answer these questions and much more about the rise of crypto.

#financialtimes #cryptocurrency #crypto #finance #bitcoin #money

The FT tells the story of Carlos Ghosn, the superstar chief executive who built the global carmaking alliance between Renault, Nissan and Mitsubishi. It is the tale of how a globetrotting industry titan with the world at his fingertips became an international fugitive.

node.title: Carlos Ghosn: the rise and fall of a superstar CEO

node.text:
An Afghan photojournalist, former politician, young musician, NATO interpreter, female filmmaker, and a student whose mother was assassinated, reveal the impact of war... as US troops pull out and the Taliban gain ground.

#FT #financialtimes #ftfilm #afghanistan #america

node.title: How the 20-year war changed Afghanistan | FT Film

node.text:
The electric car revolutionary has built a reputation as a clean energy champion. But SpaceX has never fitted in with Elon Musk's green image. Now the tech billionaire is driving the energy-hungry crypto market. FT writers and experts weigh his climate record, both good and bad, and ask whether his green status stacks up. 

#FT #financialtimes #elonmusk #environment #gogreen #ev #tesla #spacex #climatechange #sustainable

node.title: Elon Musk: CO2 saint or sinner? | FT Film

node.text:
The pandemic has been catastrophic for the hospitality industry and, in the UK, the delay to reopening the country this month has led to more uncertainty. 

In this video, FT journalist Daniel Garrahan and food critic Tim Hayward meet Harts Group, the business behind Soho institution Quo Vadis and tapas chain Barrafina, as it opens a new Soho branch of its El Pastor taquerias. 

Watch to see what it has been like to expand a business in the middle of the pandemic.

#ft #financialtimes #instafood #foodie #pandemic #coronaviruspandemic #restaurant #crisis

node.title: Is now a good time to open a new restaurant?

node.text:
How did a token designed as a joke about a dog on the internet become worth billions of dollars? Everyone seems to have an opinion on cryptocurrency, arguably the most speculative asset class on the planet, and definitely one of the most divisive. FT markets editor Katie Martin and markets news editor Adam Samson offer a beginner's guide to crypto and explain why the establishment can no longer ignore it. 

#financialtimes #cryptocurrency #crypto #bitcoin #ether #dogecoin

node.title: Why every Dogecoin has its day - crypto explained

node.text:
We gave up our privacy to fight Covid-19. Can we get it back?

In this FT Film, written by playwright James Graham, a suspected Covid-19 super spreader played by Lydia West (It's a Sin) is interrogated by a data analyst played by Arthur Darvill (Dr Who).

node.title: We know what you did during lockdown. An FT Film written by James Graham

node.text: The story of Greensill Capital's rise and fall has everything: investment banks, opaque finance, private jets, trophy mansions and the biggest British lobbying scandal in a generation, involving former prime minister David Cameron. The FT charts the rise of Lex Greensill and Sanjeev Gupta and examines where it all went wrong

node.title: Greensill: a tale of hubris, hype and greed

node.text:
China and Russia: a friendship rekindled in space?

The two powers have signed a deal to build a Moon base together as they seek to rival the US in space. 

FT global China editor James Kynge and Moscow bureau chief Henry Foy look at how the countries' partnership might develop and why they teamed up.

#FT #FinancialTimes #China #Russia #Moon #space

node.title: China, Russia and the new space race

node.text:
Streaming had already revolutionised the music business when the pandemic came to bring another layer of disruption. 

Watch our new documentary in which our video journalist @mediadon follows an up-and-coming artist as he tries to make a living during the pandemic, explaining what the new disruptions mean for the relationship between record labels and artists. 

#ft #financialtimes #music #pandemic #covidcrisis #streaming #Spotify #business #recordlabels #art #artist

node.title: How to make money in the music business

node.text: Anna Sophie Gross and John Burn-Murdoch answer your questions on the vaccines, from efficacy to safety and much more

node.title: Q&A: your questions answered on Covid-19 vaccines

buttons.text: COVID-19 vaccines go through many tests for safety and effectiveness and are then monitored closely. (Source: World Health Organization)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Financial Times on September 15, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Why are Covid vaccine boosters needed and who will receive them?'.

node.text:
Will you need a Covid booster jab? Swipe right to find out 👉

With the decision to offer Covid-19 vaccine boosters to a swath of the population, the UK joins nine other nations — including the US, France and Israel — that have announced similar campaigns.

Click on the link in our bio to read more.

#ft #financialtimes #covid #covid19 #coronavirus #pandemic #health #vaccine #jabs

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Financial Times on September 15, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Why are Covid vaccine boosters needed and who will receive them?'.

buttons.text: COVID-19 vaccines go through many tests for safety and effectiveness and are then monitored closely. (Source: World Health Organization)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Financial Times on September 15, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Why are are booster campaigns needed? Boosters are aimed at combating the waning immunity that has prompted an uptick in infec- tions even among highly vaccinated populations. The level of protection provided by vaccines against severe disease and death wanes in the period beyond three months after a second dose, according to data published on Tuesday by Public Health England.'.

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Financial Times on September 15, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and text that says 'Who in the UK will receive boosters? The UK booster rollout will begin next week, with elderly care-home residents to be offered jabs first. This will be followed by adults aged 50 years or over, frontline health and social care workers and younger adults with underlying health conditions.'.

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Financial Times on September 15, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'What's happening in other countries? Nine other countries have also decided to offer Covid-19 vaccine boosters, including the US, France, Turkey and Israel. France began administering booster doses to those over the age of 65 and with underlying health conditions earlier this month. Ireland will offer a booster dose of mRNA Covid-19 vaccines for over-80s and people over 65 living in care homes.'.

buttons.text: COVID-19 vaccines go through many tests for safety and effectiveness and are then monitored closely. (Source: World Health Organization)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Financial Times on September 15, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'What are the experts saying? Some influential dissenters including World Health Organization scientists argue that boosters are not needed because vaccines remain highly effective at preventing severe disease several months after a second dose, even against the more infectious Delta variant. Ana- Ana-Maria Henao- Restrepo, a WHO vaccines expert, said the shots administered as boosters would be better given out to countries with low vaccination rates. While Chris Whitty, England's chief medical officer, insisted that "the logic of boosters for the UK is clear and science- science-based".'.

Photo by Financial Times on September 14, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Job vacancies vacancies in the UK have shot past 1m for the first time Total number of vacancies in the UK (0OOs) 1000 800 600 400 2001 200 2005 2010 Source: ONS 2015 0 2020 FINANCIAL TIMES'.

node.text:
For the first time ever, more than a million jobs need to be filled in the UK, according to the Office for National Statistics. The unemployment rate stood at 4.6% in the three months to July.⁠
⁠
These figures will support the government’s assertion that the jobs market has recovered to a point where it can withdraw wage subsidies and other emergency income support introduced during the pandemic.⁠
⁠
Tony Wilson, director of the Institute for Employment Studies, said the figures showed 'that we’ve seen the biggest fall in the size of the labour market since the early 90s recession', with more than half a million fewer people either in or looking for work than before the pandemic began. 'The biggest risk we’re now facing is not enough workers rather than not enough jobs.'⁠
⁠
The challenge for the government will be how to fill these vacancies in a post-Brexit world - tap on the link in our bio to read more⁠
#financialtimes #jobs #unemployment #ukeconomy #furlough #brexit

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Financial Times on September 13, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'You leave your soul and your heart, and it's just your body trying to move forward. Everything was left behind, including my identity Salma Alokosai A 31-vear-old Afghan woman who was recently evacuated from Kabul, suddenly a refugee FTWEEKEND PODCAST'.

node.text:
Salma Alokosai was a young professional in Afghanistan, working with the IMF and the World Bank. Now she’s sitting in limbo at a beach resort in Albania, with hundreds of other Afghans, waiting for her paperwork.⁠
⁠
She’s one of thousands fleeing the country, and mourning the future they felt they were promised. ⁠
⁠
We hear from Salma on the new @ft_weekend podcast, which brings human stories from the news to your ears. Hosted by @lilahrap, this week we go to downtown Manhattan, Kabul and Albania to explore the ripple effects of 9/11. ⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to subscribe and listen to this episode on your podcast app of choice.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Financial Times in London, United Kingdom. May be an image of sky and text that says 'London is at risk oflosing its status as the world's top financial centre 2AO আCয়'.

node.text:
London, you've been warned. ⁠
⁠
The UK capital's position as a leading global financial centre is under threat without reforms to tax and labour rules to strengthen international trade links and expand into new markets. ⁠
⁠
London had declined relative to its biggest competitors such as New York and Hong Kong over the past decade, TheCityUK said. ⁠
⁠
The group has drawn up a strategy working with 60 financial services groups that it said would help the UK 'regain financial centre leadership in five years'.⁠
⁠
Will London turn things around? ⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to read more.⁠
⁠
📸: Dan Kitwood

node.text:
Larry Silverstein, who owned the Twin Towers, is a living link between 9/11 and the pandemic and, rather unexpectedly, he has come to be the embodiment of a great city’s resolve.

Can he rebuild the city and help it rebound?

Tap the link in our bio to read our piece on the billionaire property developer.

Animation created by @stevendbernard.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Financial Times on September 06, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Two Belarus activists have been sentenced to decade-long jail terms'.

node.text:
A Belarusian court has sentenced two opposition leaders to decade-long prison sentences.⁠
⁠
Maria Kolesnikova masterminded a campaign against President Alexander Lukashenko in last year's election and then led protests against his contested victory. She was sentenced to 11 years in jail at a closed trial in Minsk.⁠
⁠
Maxim Znak, a lawyer who served as part of the opposition's leadership, was sentenced to 10 years in a maximum-security facility on the same changes, which included 'plotting to seize state power unconstitutionally' and 'creating an extremist group'.⁠
⁠
Lukashenko, who has ruled the country with an iron fist since 1994, has accused the west of trying to engineer his downfall or assassinate him.⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our profile to read more. 📸 Ramil Nasibulin/BELTA/AFP/Getty Images⁠
⁠
#Belarus #MariaKolesnikova #AlexanderLukashenko #MaximZnak #Minsk

node.text:
Is cryptocurrency a fad? It may be dismissed as such in advanced economies, but crypto holds more appeal in countries with a history of financial instability. ⁠
⁠
In Lagos, Nigeria’s commercial capital, a software coder bills her client in London and is paid in bitcoin, sidestepping a costly banking system and the naira currency’s miserly official exchange rate. Individuals and businesses in Vietnam invest, trade and transact so much in bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies that the south-east Asian nation has the world’s highest rate of crypto adoption.⁠
⁠
‘While everyone was paying attention to [Tesla chief executive] Elon Musk’s tweets, and which institutional investor or CEO was saying what they thought about bitcoin, there was this entire story unravelling in emerging markets around the world that’s really powerful,’ says Kim Grauer, director of research at Chainalysis, a leading data company in the sector. ‘There’s a massive crypto footprint in many of these countries . . . [and] a massive amount of entrepreneurial opportunity.’⁠
⁠
So, while the financial sector in advanced economies views cryptocurrencies with suspicion — the domain of zealous ‘crypto bros’, and a speculative, highly volatile fad — emerging markets are fertile ground for cryptocurrencies, often because their own are failing to do their job. ⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read more on how crypto is quietly building deeper roots in the developing world.⁠
⁠
#FT #financialtimes #crypto #cruptocurrency #bitcoin #economy #finance #Asia #Africa #America

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Financial Times on September 03, 2021. May be an image of 3 people, people standing, outdoors and text that says 'NO!! TEXAS ABORTION BAN!! OUTRAGED!! Corporate America is staying silent on the Texas abortion ban. Why?'.

node.text:
Large US companies that have spoken out on issues such as voting rights, racial equality and transgender recognition in recent years are so far dodging the polarising debate over abortion as some of the country’s tightest restrictions go into effect in Texas. ⁠
⁠
The ‘heartbeat’ law bans abortions after cardiac activity is detected, usually around six weeks of pregnancy, before many women know that they are pregnant. It will increase the average driving distance for a Texan seeking an abortion 20-fold, from 12 miles to 248 miles, according to the Guttmacher Institute. ⁠
⁠
It also creates a reward of at least $10,000 for anyone who successfully sues an abortion provider, which critics have called an effective bounty on health workers.⁠
⁠
The law, which was left in place following a narrow 5-4 US Supreme Court decision in the early hours of Wednesday, has inflamed the national debate over women’s reproductive rights. ⁠
⁠
‘These types of hateful and discriminatory legislative steps only hurt our ability as a state to attract businesses, tourism and top-level talent, impacting our continued economic prosperity,’ said Tina Cannon, the chief executive of the Austin LGBT Chamber of Commerce.⁠
⁠
But unlike other social issues in recent years, it has yet to prompt an intervention from a large US company. Some smaller companies, however, have decided to take a stand.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read more about the polarising law and people’s reaction to it. ⁠
⁠
📷: Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images⁠
⁠
#FT #financialtimes #texas #heartbeatlaw #america #usa #womensrights

node.text:
Is cryptocurrency here to stay? What’s the future of bitcoin? Will crypto ever surpass the dollar as the world’s main currency? And the infamous question, why is the FT’s coverage of crypto usually so negative?

Watch our live with FT Alphaville reporter @jemimajo and our tech reporter @mshannahmurphy as they answer these questions and much more about the rise of crypto.

#financialtimes #cryptocurrency #crypto #finance #bitcoin #money

node.text:
A day after the last US troops flew out of Kabul and ended their 20-year military presence in Afghanistan, Joe Biden launched his most forceful defence yet of America’s chaotic exit from the country.⁠
⁠
The president said his hands had been tied by his predecessor, Donald Trump, who signed a deal with the Taliban to withdraw all US forces from Afghanistan by May 1.⁠
⁠
He also explained that the pullout marked the start of a new chapter in American foreign policy under his watch — one that will reject large troop deployments and nation-building around the world. ‘This decision about Afghanistan is not just about Afghanistan — it’s about ending an era of major military operations to remake other countries,’ he said.⁠
⁠
Biden continued his statement saying, ‘to those asking for a third decade of war in Afghanistan, I ask, ‘what is the vital national interest?’ In my view, we only have one: to make sure Afghanistan can never be used again to launch an attack on our homeland.’⁠
⁠
But the president has faced harsh criticism for the disorderly and deadly nature of the withdrawal. He acknowledged that his administration had wrongly assumed the Afghan army would be able to prevent the Taliban from conquering the country at lightning speed but insisted the chaotic airlift — which evacuated more than 100,000 people — had been a success.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read more about Biden’s statement and the aftermath of the US’s withdrawal from Afghanistan.⁠
⁠
⁠
#FT #financialtimes #afghanistan #usa #amercia #biden #kabul #middleeast #asia

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Financial Times on August 31, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Xi Jinping has collided with economic reality. His crackdown on private enterprise has been a significant drag on the economy GEORGE SOROS, FOUNDER OF SOROS FUND MANAGEMENT'.

node.text:
Investors in Xi Jinping's China face a rude awakening, according to George Soros, who says foreign investors are failing to recognise the risks of investing in a country where the leader is putting in place an updated version of Mao Zedong's party.⁠
⁠
That includes not only those who are conscious of what they are doing, but also a much larger number of people who have exposure via pension funds and other retirement savings.⁠
⁠
Tap on the link in our bio to read Soros's column for the FT, where he argues that Xi's crackdown on private enterprise shows he does not understand the market economy. Do you agree or disagree? Tell us below.⁠
⁠
#financialtimes #china #georgesoros #xijinping
